facts.text: This is Criminal Appeal No. 37 of 1965 before the Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CRIMINAL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Criminal Appeal No. 37 of 1965.

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated November 9, 1964 of the Patna High Court in Criminal Appeal No. 200 of 1964 and Death Reference No. 9 of 1964.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated November 9, 1964 of the Patna High Court in Criminal Appeal No. 200 of 1964 and Death Reference No. 9 of 1964.

facts.text: Appellant charged under section 302 of the Indian Penal Code for murdering his aunt Ratni, her daughter Chamin, her son-in-law Somra and Dilu son of Somra.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant was charged under s. 302 of the Indian Penal Code for murdering his aunt, Ratni, her daugh- ter. Chamin, her son-in-law, Somra and Dilu, son of somra.

facts.text: Appellant convicted and sentenced to death by the Judicial Commissioner of Chotanagpur.

anchor.surface_text: He was companyvicted and sentenced to death by the Judicial Commis- sioner of Chotanagpur.

facts.text: Patna High Court accepted the death reference, confirmed the conviction and sentence and dismissed the appeal preferred by the appellant.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court of Patna accepted the death reference, companyfirmed the companyviction and sentence and dismissed the appeal preferred by the appellant.

facts.text: On August 11, 1963 between 7 a.m. and 8 a.m. the appellant murdered Somra in a forest known as Dungijharan Hills.

anchor.surface_text: The prosecution case is that on August 11, 1963 between 7 a.m. and 8 a.m. the appellant murdered Somra in a forest known as Dungijharan Hills

facts.text: Appellant later murdered Chamin in Kesari Garha field on August 11, 1963.

anchor.surface_text: and later Chamin in Kesari Garha field and then Ratni and Dilu in the house of Ratni at village Jamtoli.

facts.text: Appellant murdered Ratni and Dilu in the house of Ratni at village Jamtoli on August 11, 1963.

anchor.surface_text: and later Chamin in Kesari Garha field and then Ratni and Dilu in the house of Ratni at village Jamtoli.

facts.text: First information of the offences lodged by the appellant himself at police station Palkot on August 11, 1963 at 3:15 p.m.

anchor.surface_text: The first information of the offences was lodged by the appellant himself at police station Palkot on August 11, 1963 at 3-15 p.m.

facts.text: Information reduced to writing by Sub-Inspector H. P. Choudhury, and appellant affixed left thumb-impression on the report.

anchor.surface_text: The information was reduced to writing by the officerin-charge, Sub-Inspector H. P. Choudhury, and the appellant affixed his left thumb-impression on the report.

facts.text: Sub-Inspector immediately took cognizance of the offence and arrested the appellant.

anchor.surface_text: The Sub Inspector immediately took companynizance of the offence, and arrested the appellant.

facts.text: Next day, Sub-Inspector in company of appellant went to house of Ratni where appellant pointed out dead bodies of Ratni and Dilu and place where he concealed a tangi.

anchor.surface_text: The next day, the Sub Inspector in the companypany of the appellant went to the house of Ratni, where the appellant pointed out the dead bodies of Ratni and Dilu and also a place in the orchard of Ratni companyered with bushes and grass, where he had companycealed a tangi.

facts.text: Appellant took Sub-Inspector and witnesses to Kasiari garha khet and pointed out dead body of Chamin in a ditch covered with Ghanghu.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant then took the Sub Inspector and witnesses to Kasiari garha khet and pointed out the dead body of Chamin lying in a ditch companyered with Ghanghu.

facts.text: Appellant took Sub-Inspector and witnesses to Dungijharan Hills and pointed out dead body of Somra on slope of the hills to the north.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant then took the Sub Inspector and the witnesses to Dungijharan Hills, where he pointed out the dead body of Somra lying in the slope of the hills to the numberth.

facts.text: Sub-Inspector recovered from appellant's house a chadar stained with human blood.

anchor.surface_text: The Sub Inspector also recovered from the appellants house a chadar stained with human blood.

facts.text: Evidence of P.W. 6 shows appellant went to the forest on the morning of August 11, 1963.

anchor.surface_text: The evidence of P.W. 6 shows that the appellant had gone to the forest on the morning of August 11, 1963.

facts.text: Medical evidence discloses incised wounds on all dead bodies caused by sharp-cutting weapon such as tangi.

anchor.surface_text: The medical evidence discloses incised wounds on all the dead bodies. The injuries were caused by a sharp-cutting weapon such as a tangi.

facts.text: All four persons were brutally murdered.

anchor.surface_text: All the four persons were brutally murdered.

facts.text: There is no eye-witness to the murders.

anchor.surface_text: There is numbereye-witness to the murders.

facts.text: Appellant is Aghnu Nagesia, son of Lodhi Nagesia, resident of Lotwa, Tola Jamtoli, thana Palkot, district Ranchi.

anchor.surface_text: My name is Aghnu Nagesia.  1  My fathers name is Lodhi Nagesia. I am a resident of Lotwa, Tola Jamtoli, thana Palkot, district Ranchi.

facts.text: Appellant lodged FIR at about 3 p.m. on Sunday (date not known).

anchor.surface_text: Today, Sunday, date number known, at about 3 p.m. I having companye to the P.S. make statement before you the S.I. of Police

facts.text: Sub-Inspector arrested appellant after FIR leading to discovery.

anchor.surface_text: Now, the Sub Inspector stated that he arrested the appellant after he gave the first information report leading to the discovery.

facts.text: Blood-stained chadar discovered from appellant's house.

anchor.surface_text: the discovery of a blood-stained chadar from the appellants house

facts.text: Appellant went to Dungi Jharan Hills on morning of August 11, 1963.

anchor.surface_text: and the fact that he had gone to Dungi Jharan Hills on the morning of August 11, 1963.

facts.text: If first information report excluded, other evidence insufficient to convict appellant.

anchor.surface_text: If this report is excluded, the other evidence on the record is insufficient to companyvict the appellant.

issues.text: The principal question in the appeal is whether the statement or any portion of it is admissible in evidence

anchor.surface_text: The principal evid- ence against the appellant companysists of the first information report, which companytains a full companyfession of guilt by the appellant. If this report is excluded, the other evidence on the record is insufficient to companyvict the appellant. The principal question in the appeal is whether the statement or any portion of it is admissible in evidence.

issues.text: whether the entire statement is a confession made to a police officer and is not provable against the appellant, having regard to S. 25 of the Indian Evidence Act, 1872

anchor.surface_text: On behalf of the appellant, it is companytended that the entire statement is a companyfession made to a police officer and is number provable against the appellant, having regard to S. 25 of the Indian Evidence Act, 1872.

issues.text: whether S. 25 protects only those portions of the statement which disclose the killings by the appellant and the rest of the statement is not protected by s. 25

anchor.surface_text: On behalf of the respondent, it is companytended that S. 25 protects only those portions of the statement which disclose the killings by the appellant and the rest of the statement is number protected by s. 25.

issues.text: whether the separability test applies such that parts of the confessional first information report are admissible apart from those excluded by s.25

anchor.surface_text: Some of the decided cases took the view that if a part of the report is property severable from the strict companyfessional part, then the severable part companyld be tendered in evidence. We think that the separability test is misleading,

issues.text: whether the appellant was in the custody of a police officer when he gave the first information report for the purposes of Section 27

anchor.surface_text: Section 27 applies only to information received from a person accused of an offence in the custody of a police officer. Now, the Sub Inspector stated that he arrested the appellant after he gave the first information report leading to the discovery. Prima facie, therefore, the appellant was number in the custody of a police officer when he gave the report,

issues.text: whether a person directly giving information to a police officer which may be used against him may be deemed to have submitted to the custody of the police officer within the meaning of s.27

anchor.surface_text: On the question whether a person directly giving to a police officer information which may be used as evidence against him -may be deemed to have submitted himself to the custody of the police officer within the meaning of s. 27, there is companyflict of opinion.

arguments.claim: The entire statement is a confession made to a police officer and is not provable against the appellant under Section 25 of the Indian Evidence Act.

anchor.surface_text: On behalf of the appellant, it is contended that the entire statement is a confession made to a police officer and is not provable against the appellant, having regard to S. 25 of the Indian Evidence Act, 1872.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: out the dead body of Chamin lying in a ditch companyered with Ghanghu. The appellant then took the Sub Inspector and the witnesses to Dungijharan Hill

arguments.court_reasoning: Court agreed the FIR is a confessional statement as a whole but allowed formal parts identifying the maker and portions under S.27.

arguments.claim: Section 25 protects only those portions of the statement which disclose the killings by the appellant and the rest of the statement is not protected by S.25.

anchor.surface_text: On behalf of the respondent, it is contended that S. 25 protects only those portions of the statement which disclose the killings by the appellant and the rest of the statement is not protected by s. 25.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: R. 2 Rajasthan 93. A.I.R. 1964 Patna 210. Section 27 applies only to information received from a person accused of an offence in the custody of a poli

arguments.court_reasoning: Separability test is misleading; if confessional, taint attaches to entire statement including all incriminating parts.

arguments.claim: The first information report is a confessional statement as a whole containing admission of the offence and related incriminating facts.

anchor.surface_text: The principal evidence against the appellant consists of the first information report, which contains a full confession of guilt by the appellant. If this report is excluded, the other evidence on the record is insufficient to convict the appellant.

arguments.claim: Section 25 provides an absolute ban on proving any confession made to a police officer against the accused under any circumstances.

anchor.surface_text: Section 25 of the Evidence Act is one of the provisions of law dealing with confessions made by an accused... No confession made to a police officer, shall be proved as against a person accused of an offence.

arguments.claim: Confession is a species of admission defined as a statement admitting the offence or substantially all facts constituting it; self-exculpatory parts may negate if true.

anchor.surface_text: The Indian Evidence Act does not define confession... a confession is an admission made at any time by a person charged with crime, stating or suggesting the inference that he committed that crime.

arguments.court_reasoning: Approved in Palvinder Kaur and State of Bombay v. Kathi Kalu; discarded Stephen's definition per Pakala Narayanaswami.

arguments.claim: If a confessional statement is tainted under S.24, S.25 or S.26, the entire statement including all incriminating parts is inadmissible.

anchor.surface_text: If the confession is tainted, the taint attaches to each part of it. It is not permissible in law to separate one part and to admit it in evidence as a non-confessional statement.

arguments.claim: The separability test for admitting non-confessional parts of a confessional FIR is misleading and incorrect.

anchor.surface_text: Some of the decided cases took the view that if a part of the report is properly severable from the strict confessional part, then the severable part could be tendered in evidence. We think that the separability test is misleading,

arguments.court_reasoning: Entire confessional statement hit by S.25 except formal parts and S.27; distinguished conflicting High Court views.

arguments.claim: The appellant was not in the custody of a police officer when he gave the first information report, so S.27 does not apply.
arguments.court_reasoning: Assumed constructive custody for argument's sake but noted conflict of opinion.

arguments.claim: Provisions on confessions (Ss.24-26 Evidence Act, S.162 CrPC) based on public policy distrusting such statements, requiring fullest effect.

anchor.surface_text: These provisions seem to proceed upon the view that confessions made by an accused to a police officer or made by him while he is in the custody of a police officer are not to be trusted, and should not be used in evidence against him. They are based upon grounds of public policy,

arguments.claim: High Court erred in admitting non-formal parts of the FIR beyond S.27; only parts 1,15,18 and S.27 portions admissible.

anchor.surface_text: We think, therefore, that save and except parts 1, 15 and 18 identifying the appellant as the maker of the first information report and save and except the portions coming within the purview of s. 27, the entire first information report must be excluded from evidence.

holdings.text: The first information report contains a full confession of guilt by the appellant.

anchor.surface_text: The principal evidence against the appellant consists of the first information report, which contains a full confession of guilt by the appellant.

holdings.reasoning_summary: FIR admits offence and substantially all facts constituting murders; applies definition from precedents like Pakala Narayanaswami.

holdings.text: Section 25 of the Evidence Act provides an absolute ban: no confession made to a police officer shall be proved against the accused under any circumstances.

anchor.surface_text: Section 25 of the Evidence Act is one of the provisions of law dealing with confessions made by an accused... No confession made to a police officer, shall be proved as against a person accused of an offence.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual interpretation of imperative terms; covers confessions whether free or in custody, before or during investigation.

holdings.text: If a statement is confessional, the taint under ss.24,25,26 attaches to the entire statement including all incriminating parts; no separation permitted.

anchor.surface_text: If the confession is tainted, the taint attaches to each part of it. It is not permissible in law to separate one part and to admit it in evidence as a non-confessional statement.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Each part partakes of confessional character; otherwise ss.24-26 lose content; harmonious construction with s.27.

holdings.text: The separability test is misleading; entire confessional FIR hit by s.25 except formal parts identifying maker and s.27 portions.

anchor.surface_text: Some of the decided cases took the view that if a part of the report is properly severable from the strict confessional part, then the severable part could be tendered in evidence. We think that the separability test is misleading,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Rejects High Court views applying separability; policy requires full protection; distinguished conflicting precedents.

holdings.text: Save parts 1,15,18 identifying maker and s.27 portions, entire FIR excluded from evidence.

anchor.surface_text: We think, therefore, that save and except parts 1, 15 and 18 identifying the appellant as the maker of the first information report and save and except the portions coming within the purview of s. 27, the entire first information report must be excluded from evidence.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Application of s.25 to whole after rejecting separability; formal parts admissible as conduct under s.8.

holdings.text: Appellant was prima facie not in custody of police officer when giving FIR; arrested after.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Fact from Sub-Inspector's statement; s.27 requires custody.

holdings.text: Provisions ss.24-26 Evidence Act and s.162 CrPC based on public policy distrusting police confessions; fullest effect to be given.

anchor.surface_text: These provisions seem to proceed upon the view that confessions made by an accused to a police officer or made by him while he is in the custody of a police officer are not to be trusted, and should not be used in evidence against him. They are based upon grounds of public policy,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Purposive interpretation to protect accused from unreliable statements.

holdings.text: Confession is an admission stating or suggesting inference that accused committed crime; must admit offence or substantially all facts; self-exculpatory negates if true.

anchor.surface_text: The Indian Evidence Act does not define confession. For a long time, the Courts in India adopted the definition... a confession is an admission made at any time by a person charged with crime, stating or suggesting the inference that he committed that crime.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Follows Judicial Committee in Pakala Narayanaswami, approved in Palvinder Kaur.
